titleStmt.title: SOLIS DAN, to Don-Quixote of the Mancha.

publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

analytic.title: SOLIS DAN, to Don-Quixote of the Mancha.

monogr.title: The history of the valorovs and vvittie knight-errant, Don-Qvixote of the Mancha. Translated out of the Spanish
monogr.author: Cervantes Saavedra, Miguel de

div.head: SOLIS DAN, to Don-Quixote of the Mancha.

lg.l: MAugre the rauings, that are set abroach,
And rumble vp and downe thy troubled braine:
Yet none thine acts Quixote can reproach
Or thy proceedings taxe as vile, or vaine.
Thy feates shalbe, thy fairest ornament
(Seeing wrongs to'ndoe, thou goest thus about)
Although, with blowes, a thousand times y-shent
Thou wert, well nigh, yee'uen by the miscreant route.
And if thy faire Dulcinea, shall wrong
And to thy cares will lend no lightning eare.
Then let this comfort all thy woes out weare
That Sancho faild in brokers occupation,
He foolish, cruell shee: thou, without tongue.
